description: From pre- (“before”) +‎ history, first attested in the Foreign Quarterly Review in 1836, after the model of prehistoric, from French préhistorique.

entries.meaning: The time before written records in any area of the world; the events and conditions of those times.
(humorous, hyperbolic) Any past time (even recent) treated as such a distant, unknowable era.
examples: I was a town boy through and through. The country belonged to a vague pre-history.

entries.meaning: (often as pre-history) The history leading up to some event, condition, etc.
examples: Psychologists... are mostly bad historians, inventing—as Freud has done—their pre-history to suit their theories.
